content: Can you provide 3 case laws of cases that have gone through a 3-hop court levels.

Here are three Kenyan case laws that have gone through at least three court levels (e.g., Magistrate’s Court, High Court, Court of Appeal, Supreme Court), with their names, citations, and brief summaries:

---

1. Francis Karioko Muruatetu & Another v Republic
   - High Court: [2014] eKLR
   - Court of Appeal: [2016] eKLR
   - Supreme Court: [2017] eKLR
   - Summary: Muruatetu and another were convicted of murder and sentenced to death. They challenged the constitutionality of the mandatory death sentence. The Supreme Court declared the mandatory death penalty unconstitutional, requiring courts to consider mitigating circumstances in sentencing.
   - [Supreme Court Decision](http://kenyalaw.org/caselaw/cases/view/140283/)

2. Geoffrey Andare v Attorney General & 2 others
   - Magistrate’s Court: Criminal Case No. 1021 of 2011 (unreported)
   - High Court: [2015] eKLR
   - Court of Appeal: [2016] eKLR
   - Supreme Court: [2021] eKLR
   - Summary: Andare was charged under Section 29 of the Kenya Information and Communications Act. He challenged the section as unconstitutional. The Supreme Court affirmed the unconstitutionality of Section 29, upholding freedom of expression.
   - [Supreme Court Decision](http://kenyalaw.org/caselaw/cases/view/210264/)

3. Samuel Kamau Macharia & Another v Kenya Commercial Bank Ltd & 2 Others
   - High Court: [2006] eKLR
   - Court of Appeal: [2010] eKLR
   - Supreme Court: [2012] eKLR
   - Summary: Macharia challenged the Supreme Court’s jurisdiction to hear appeals from decisions made before the 2010 Constitution. The Supreme Court held its jurisdiction is limited to matters under the 2010 Constitution and cannot be exercised retroactively.
   - [Supreme Court Decision](http://kenyalaw.org/caselaw/cases/view/78750/)

If you need more details on any of these cases or further guidance on Kenyan appellate procedure, please let me know!
